013package org.apache.juneau.annotation;
014
015import static java.lang.annotation.ElementType.*;
016import static java.lang.annotation.RetentionPolicy.*;
017
018import java.lang.annotation.*;
019
020import org.apache.juneau.*;
021
022/**
023 * Maps constructor arguments to property names on beans with read-only properties.
024 *
025 * <p>
026 * Can be used in the following locations:
027 * <ul>
028 *    <li>Bean constructors.
029 *    <li><ja>@Rest</ja>-annotated classes and <ja>@RestOp</ja>-annotated methods when an {@link #on()} value is specified.
030 * </ul>
031
032 * <p>
033 * This annotation can be used in the case of beans with properties whose values can only be set by passing them in
034 * through a constructor on the class.
035 * <br>Since method parameter names are lost during compilation, this annotation essentially redefines them so that they
036 * are available at runtime.
037 *
038 * <p>
039 * This annotation can only be applied to constructors and can only be applied to one constructor per class.
040 *
041 * <p>
042 * When present, bean instantiation is delayed until the call to {@link BeanMap#getBean()}.
043 * Until then, bean property values are stored in a local cache until <c>getBean()</c> is called.
044 * Because of this additional caching step, parsing into read-only beans tends to be slower and use more memory than
045 * parsing into beans with writable properties.
046 *
047 * <p>
048 * Attempting to call {@link BeanMap#put(String,Object)} on a read-only property after calling {@link BeanMap#getBean()}
049 * will result in a {@link BeanRuntimeException} being thrown.
050 * Multiple calls to {@link BeanMap#getBean()} will return the same bean instance.
051 *
052 * <h5 class='section'>See Also:</h5><ul>
053 *    <li class='link'><a class="doclink" href="https://juneau.apache.org/docs/topics/BeancAnnotation">@Beanc Annotation</a>
054 * </ul>
055 */
056@Documented
057@Target({METHOD,TYPE,CONSTRUCTOR})
058@Retention(RUNTIME)
059@Inherited
060@Repeatable(BeancAnnotation.Array.class)
061@ContextApply(BeancAnnotation.Applier.class)
062public @interface Beanc {
063
064    /**
065     * Optional description for the exposed API.
066     *
067     * @return The annotation value.
068     * @since 9.2.0
069     */
070    String[] description() default {};
071
072    /**
073    * Dynamically apply this annotation to the specified constructors.
074    *
075    * <p>
076    * Used in conjunction with {@link org.apache.juneau.BeanContext.Builder#applyAnnotations(Class...)} to dynamically apply an annotation to an existing constructor.
077    * It is ignored when the annotation is applied directly to constructors.
078    *
079    * <p>
080    * The following example shows this annotation in use:
081    * <p class='bjava'>
082    *    <jc>// Our read-only bean.</jc>
083    *    <jk>public class</jk> Person {
084    *       <jk>private final</jk> String <jf>name</jf>;
085    *       <jk>private final int</jk> <jf>age</jf>;
086    *
087    *       <jk>public</jk> Person(String <jv>name</jv>, <jk>int</jk> <jv>age</jv>) {
088    *          <jk>this</jk>.<jf>name</jf> = <jv>name</jv>;
089    *          <jk>this</jk>.<jf>age</jf> = <jv>age</jv>;
090    *       }
091    *
092    *       <jc>// Read only properties.</jc>
093    *       <jc>// Getters, but no setters.</jc>
094    *
095    *       <jk>public</jk> String getName() {
096    *          <jk>return</jk> <jf>name</jf>;
097    *       }
098    *
099    *       <jk>public int</jk> getAge() {
100    *          <jk>return</jk> <jf>age</jf>;
101    *       }
102    *    }
103    *
104    *    <ja>@BeanConfig</ja>
105    *    <ja>@Beanc</ja>(on=<js>"Person(String,int)"</js>, properties=<js>"name,age"</js>))
106    *    <jk>public static class</jk> MyConfig {}
107    * </p>
108    * <p class='bjava'>
109    *    <jc>// Parsing into a read-only bean.</jc>
110    *    String <jv>json</jv> = <js>"{name:'John Smith',age:45}"</js>;
111    *    Person <jv>person</jv> = JsonParser.<jsf>DEFAULT</jsf>.copy().applyAnnotations(MyConfig.<jk>class</jk>).build().parse(<jv>json</jv>);
112    *    String <jv>name</jv> = <jv>person</jv>.getName();  <jc>// "John Smith"</jc>
113    *    <jk>int</jk> <jv>age</jv> = <jv>person</jv>.getAge();   <jc>// 45</jc>
114    * </p>
115    *
116    * <h5 class='section'>Valid patterns:</h5>
117    * <ul class='spaced-list'>
118    *    <li>Constructors:
119    *       <ul>
120    *          <li>Fully qualified with args:
121    *             <ul>
122    *                <li><js>"com.foo.MyClass(String,int)"</js>
123    *                <li><js>"com.foo.MyClass(java.lang.String,int)"</js>
124    *                <li><js>"com.foo.MyClass()"</js>
125    *             </ul>
126    *          <li>Simple with args:
127    *             <ul>
128    *                <li><js>"MyClass(String,int)"</js>
129    *                <li><js>"MyClass(java.lang.String,int)"</js>
130    *                <li><js>"MyClass()"</js>
131    *             </ul>
132    *          <li>Simple inner class:
133    *             <ul>
134    *                <li><js>"MyClass$Inner1$Inner2()"</js>
135    *                <li><js>"Inner1$Inner2()"</js>
136    *                <li><js>"Inner2()"</js>
137    *             </ul>
138    *       </ul>
139    *    <li>A comma-delimited list of anything on this list.
140    * </ul>
141    *
142    * <h5 class='section'>See Also:</h5><ul>
143    *    <li class='link'><a class="doclink" href="https://juneau.apache.org/docs/topics/DynamicallyAppliedAnnotations">Dynamically Applied Annotations</a>
144    * </ul>
145    *
146    * @return The annotation value.
147    */
148   String[] on() default {};
149
150   /**
151    * The names of the properties of the constructor arguments.
152    *
153    * <p>
154    * The {@link org.apache.juneau.annotation.Beanc @Beanc} annotation is used to map constructor arguments to property
155    * names on bean with read-only properties.
156    * <br>Since method parameter names are lost during compilation, this annotation essentially redefines them so that
157    * they are available at runtime.
158    *
159    * <p>
160    * The definition of a read-only bean is a bean with properties with only getters, like shown below:
161    * <p class='bjava'>
162    *    <jc>// Our read-only bean.</jc>
163    *    <jk>public class</jk> Person {
164    *       <jk>private final</jk> String <jf>name</jf>;
165    *       <jk>private final int</jk> <jf>age</jf>;
166    *
167    *       <ja>@Beanc</ja>(properties=<js>"name,age"</js>)
168    *       <jk>public</jk> Person(String <jv>name</jv>, <jk>int</jk> <jv>age</jv>) {
169    *          <jk>this</jk>.<jf>name</jf> = <jv>name</jv>;
170    *          <jk>this</jk>.<jf>age</jf> = <jv>age</jv>;
171    *       }
172    *
173    *       <jc>// Read only properties.</jc>
174    *       <jc>// Getters, but no setters.</jc>
175    *
176    *       <jk>public</jk> String getName() {
177    *          <jk>return</jk> <jf>name</jf>;
178    *       }
179    *
180    *       <jk>public int</jk> getAge() {
181    *          <jk>return</jk> <jf>age</jf>;
182    *       }
183    *    }
184    * </p>
185    * <p class='bjava'>
186    *    <jc>// Parsing into a read-only bean.</jc>
187    *    String <jv>json</jv> = <js>"{name:'John Smith',age:45}"</js>;
188    *    Person <jv>person</jv> = JsonParser.<jsf>DEFAULT</jsf>.parse(<jv>json</jv>);
189    *    String <jv>name</jv> = <jv>person</jv>.getName();  <jc>// "John Smith"</jc>
190    *    <jk>int</jk> <jv>age</jv> = <jv>person</jv>.getAge();   <jc>// 45</jc>
191    * </p>
192    * <p>
193    *    Note that the {@link Name @Name} annotation can also be used to identify bean property names on constructor
194    *    arguments.  If neither this annotation or {@link Name @Name} is used, then we try to get the property names
195    *    from the parameter names if they are available in the bytecode.
196    * </p>
197    *
198    * @return The annotation value.
199    */
200   String properties() default "";
201}
